definition: one side of the story/one-sided statement
one/1/single/a (article)/as soon as/entire/whole/all/throughout/"one" radical in Chinese characters (Kangxi radical 1)/also pr. [yao1] for greater clarity when spelling out numbers digit by digit
flour/noodles/(of food) soft (not crunchy)/(slang) (of a person) ineffectual/spineless
variant of 麵|面[mian4]
face/side/surface/aspect/top/classifier for flat surfaces such as drums, mirrors, flags etc
(possessive particle, literary equivalent of 的[de5])/him/her/it
old variant of 詞|词[ci2]
word/statement/speech/lyrics/CL:組|组[zu3],個|个[ge4]/a form of lyric poetry, flourishing in the Song dynasty 宋朝|宋朝[Song4 chao2]/CL:首[shou3]

sentences.english: So is this just a Wall Street trope?
sentences.chinese: Careny问到，”这仅仅是华尔街的一面之词？

sentences.english: You're hearing one side of the story.
sentences.chinese: 你听到的只是一面之词。

sentences.english: History is always written by the winners.
sentences.chinese: 就其本质而言，历史始终是一面之词。

sentences.english: You only hear Monica's side of that.
sentences.chinese: 你只听到了莫妮卡的一面之词。

sentences.english: Of course, these are digital distributors talking here.
sentences.chinese: 当然，这仅仅是数字漫画分销商的一面之词。
美国媒体都是一面之词。

sentences.english: I do not want to hear what reason says.
sentences.chinese: 我不想听理性的一面之词。

sentences.english: And I just take your word?
sentences.chinese: 而我相信你的一面之词？

sentences.english: By its very nature, history is always a one-sided account.
sentences.chinese: 就其本质而言，历史始终是一面之词。

sentences.english: He thought he would have the Arkansas press all to himself.
sentences.chinese: 他以为阿肯色州的媒体都会听他的一面之词。

sentences.english: You've only heard his side of the story.
sentences.chinese: 你只听了他的一面之词。

definition: selective listening/to hear what one wants to hear
to speak off the cuff/to casually opine
reliable evidence (idiom); conclusive proof/definitive evidence
gossip/hearsay/rumor
to assume/assumption
mere verbal statement cannot be taken as proof (idiom)
to listen to information/to get the news/to believe what one hears
to jump to an unfounded conclusion
to speak without thinking/to blurt sth out
to easily trust/gullible/naïve
empty promises
a bunch of nonsense
to speak without thinking (idiom)/to blurt sth out
to twist words and force logic (idiom)/sophistry/loud rhetoric making up for fallacious argument/shoving false arguments down people's throats
lit. right and wrong, crooked and straight (idiom); fig. merits and demerits/pros and cons
(idiom) you can't rely on a verbal agreement/just because sb says sth, doesn't mean it's true
